title: How to Paint Panel Walls

steps.headline: Wipe down the walls.
steps.description: Dip a soft rag in lukewarm water, and then ring it out until it’s damp, but not soaking wet. Starting at the top of your wall in the corner of the room, wipe down from the ceiling. If you have particularly dirty spots on the wall, you might have to go over it a few times. If there are stains on your wall, especially any caused by grease, you’ll need to use a specialized stain remover to get rid of them. Follow the directions on the remover you choose. Once you’ve removed the other stains, wipe down the walls with a damp rag.

steps.headline: Fill any nail holes.
steps.description: Look for any nail holes or other indents or imperfections in your wall. Fill each of them with spackling compound. Scoop up a bit of compound on your finger, then dab it into the hole. Once the compound is dry, use sandpaper with a medium grit (60 to 100 grit) to sand the compound down until it’s flush with the wall.

steps.headline: Sand the paneling with 100-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Use a 100-grit sandpaper attached to either a sanding pole, sanding block, or orbital sander to sand your walls. Don’t sand them all the way down to bare wood – just enough to make the surface of the wall feel rough. Wear safety glasses and a paper mask that covers your mouth. This will prevent any of the dust from irritating your eyes or lungs. You might want to put down plastic sheeting or tarps to protect your floor from dust while you sand. You can also tape plastic sheeting or tarps over doorways to prevent dust from escaping and getting into other rooms. You can also cover or remove the room's furniture.

steps.headline: Sand the trim if you’re going to paint it.
steps.description: Depending on what color you’re painting your wood paneling, you might want to repaint your trim as well. Use a 100-grit sandpaper to lightly sand the trim in the room you’re painting. Then wipe down the trim to remove any loose dust.This will allow you to paint the trim to match the walls.

steps.headline: Caulk cracks at the baseboard and around windows and doors.
steps.description: As the wood paneling ages, it might warp and create gaps between the paneling and the baseboard. You should fill any of these gaps with  caulk. You should also look for gaps around windows and doors, and any other cracks in the wall. Fill each of these with caulk and let it dry completely, at least 12 hours.

steps.headline: Use painters tape and drop cloths to protect the room.
steps.description: You should cover the floor of the room you’re painting with plastic drop cloths. These are available from most home improvement stores. You can also use plastic tarps if you have any. Use painters tape to create a barrier between where you’re painting and anywhere you don’t want paint. When you’re applying the painter’s tape, make sure you place it right at the edge of where you want the paint to go. For example, if you’re painting all the way down to the trim, put the painter’s tape on the very top edge of the trim. This lets you paint the paneling all the way down, but protects your trim.

steps.headline: Choose a roller with a medium nap.
steps.description: When you roll the paint onto the wall, you want to make sure that the paint gets into all of the grooves of the paneling. A paint roller with a medium nap should be long enough to do that. Look for rollers with nap that is about ⁄8 in (0.95 cm) long. You can get these types of rollers from most home improvement stores. If you’re unsure about the length of the nap, ask an employee for help.

steps.headline: Use water-based primer for solid wood paneling.
steps.description: If you have solid wood paneling, you’ll need to use a water-based primer. It will prevent any damage to the wood. You can find water-based primer at most home improvement stores in the paint section. To determine if the paneling is solid wood, check the edges. If you see growth rings on the edges of the panels, you have solid wood. You can choose to use a tinted primer that matches the paint color you’ve chosen. This can give you a bit more coverage and might mean you don’t have to use as much paint.

steps.headline: Use a shellac-based primer for veneer paneling.
steps.description: If your paneling is veneer, a shellac-based primer is better. It will help the paint adhere to the paneling better. Most home improvement stores have shellac-based primer in the paint section. You can tell if your walls are veneer by looking at the grain pattern. If the grain pattern repeats in large sections, it's likely your walls are veneer. Real wood would have a greater variety.

steps.headline: Prepare to cut in with primer.
steps.description: Use a 2 in (5.1 cm) angled paint brush to cut in the corners of the room. Pour about 2 in (5.1 cm) of paint into a paint tray or bucket. Dip the brush up to 2/3 of the way into the primer. Then place the longer side of the brush flush against the corner of the wall you’re painting. If you're painting the edge of the wall, hold the longer edge of the brush vertically along the edge. If you're painting at the ceiling or baseboard, hold the long edge horizontally against the wall.

steps.headline: Paint a 2 in (5.1 cm) strip of primer.
steps.description: With the longer side of the brush flat against the corner of the wall, brush on a 2 in (5.1 cm) strip of primer. Move vertically along the wall, starting at the top, if you’re painting the edge of the wall. Paint horizontally if you’re painting at the top of the wall along ceiling or baseboard. Repeat this process until you’ve got a 2 in (5.1 cm)-wide strip of paint all along the edge of the walls and ceiling. This will make it easier to then roll primer onto the rest of the wall. If you notice that the primer clumping up in the edges between the panels, swipe down the edge with your paintbrush. That should even out the primer.

steps.headline: Roll on 2 coats of primer.
steps.description: Once you’ve cut in the edges and corners, use your roller to apply 2 coats of primer. Pour about 3 in (7.6 cm) of primer into a paint tray. Then roll your roller into it, coating the whole roller. Roll the roller against the dry ledge of your paint tray to remove excess primer so your roller doesn’t drip. Then roll the primer onto the wall in vertical strips, making sure to get primer into the edges between the panels. You’ll need to let the primer completely dry in between applications. Your can of primer should tell you exactly how long to wait between coats, but it’s usually at least a couple of hours.

steps.headline: Cut in with your choice of paint.
steps.description: Following the same process as with the primer, cut in with your chosen paint color. This will help your paint job look more professional, since you won’t have to squish your roller into the corners of the room. Depending on the color you’ve chosen and the original color of your walls, you might need 2 or 3 coats of paint. You should apply this many coats even where you’re cutting in. Otherwise, the paneling might show through on your edges.

steps.headline: Roll a coat of paint onto the wall.
steps.description: Once you’re done cutting in the room with paint, you can apply the rest of the paint with a roller. Start at the edge of your cut-ins, and roll on the paint in large vertical strips. Make sure the paint gets into the edges between the paneling. Keep the paint brush you used for cutting in near you during this step. If you notice paint clumping up in the edges between panels, swipe down with the paint brush. This will remove the excess paint and make your wall look smooth.

steps.headline: Let the wall dry completely before lightly sanding it between coats.
steps.description: Sanding the paint job between coats should remove any clumps you couldn’t get with your paint brush. Wait for your paint job to be completely dry, usually overnight. Use 100-grit sandpaper on a sanding pole or orbital sander to lightly sand the walls. Wipe down the walls with a damp rag after each round of sanding. Wear safety glasses and a paper face mask while you sand. They can prevent any dust from getting into your eyes or mouth and irritating you.

steps.headline: Repeat painting and sanding until you have the desired color on your walls.
steps.description: It will probably take 2 or 3 coats of paint for the wood paneling to be completely covered. If the paneling is darker, it may take more. Allow the final coat of paint to dry overnight, and then remove any painters' tape and tarps. You can also replace furniture at this point.
